issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2) incorrectly states that controller methods take a Consumer<List<Note>> and then says that the consumer receives the internal list of persons. This contradicts both the intended design and the template/solution code, where PersonController methods take Consumer<List<Person>>. This mismatch (Note vs Person) in the documented parameter type can confuse students about the correct generic type to use when implementing the PersonController methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController API. Make the text consistent: each PersonController method takes a Consumer<List<Person>> that is called with the controller's internal List<Person> after a response is received.

issues.description: The Part 2 description in the problem statement refers to the callback parameter type as Consumer<List<Note>> when describing the PersonController methods. This conflicts with the template and solution code, where the PersonController methods use Consumer<List<Person>>. The mismatch (Note vs Person) is a likely copy/paste typo in the problem text and can confuse students about the expected generic type for the PersonController callbacks.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController methods so the textual instructions match the template and solution signatures and avoid confusing students.
